artist.name: Kathy Hinde
bio_100w: Kathy Hinde’s work grows from a partnership between nature and technology expressed through audio-visual installations and performances that combine sound, sculpture, image and light. She creates work that evolves and can be different each time it is experienced. Kathy frequently works in collaboration with other practitioners and scientists and often actively involves the audience in the creative process. Awards include an Honorary Mention at Prix Ars Electronica, a British Composer Award, an ORAM award and a Scottish Award for New Music. She became a Cryptic Artist in 2015 and is a member of the Bristol Experimental Expanded Film collective.

artwork_description_150w_long: You are invited to listen deeply to the waterways of Bristol using underwater microphones at the point where the floating harbour meets the gorge.

There are many interventions that keep Bristol’s relationship with water flowing and smooth. Together, we will contemplate the huge tidal range of the Bristol Channel by positioning ourselves at an edge point of the city, demarcated by a shifting watery passageway that carves a liminal space between the urban and the rural.
Watery compositions created from underwater sounds and shaped by tidal data, will also be integrated into the listening walk, inviting us to consider the potential future of rising sea levels.
Join together to develop a meaningful connection with the watery environs of Bristol by pausing to reflect through listening from an underwater perspective.
artwork.artwork_description_50w_short: Join together for walk to pause, reflect and listen to Bristol from an underwater perspective at the point where the floating harbour meets the gorge. Contemplate tidal changes from an edge point of the city, demarcated by a shifting watery passageway carving a space between the urban and the rural.
